title: Cutaneous Melanoma
diagnosis_topic: Cutaneous Melanoma – Diagnosis, Staging, and Surgical Management
setup_script: “A 45-year-old male presents to your clinic after his dermatologist biopsied a pigmented lesion on his upper back. The pathology confirmed melanoma. He has no significant past medical history. The biopsy site is healing well, and there is no palpable lymphadenopathy on exam. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for biopsy details
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The pathology report shows malignant melanoma with Breslow depth 2.2 mm, non-ulcerated, mitotic rate 2/mm².”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to ask for biopsy details
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The pathology report confirms melanoma, but you have not yet reviewed the histologic characteristics. Would you like that information?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends wide local excision
dynamic_flow.reply: - “What surgical margins are appropriate for this melanoma?”
- “You schedule him for wide local excision with a 2 cm margin. What additional procedure should you consider at the time of surgery?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB)
dynamic_flow.reply: - “You perform SLNB. Pathology reveals 1 of 3 sentinel nodes positive for melanoma. How does this change management?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to mention SLNB
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Final pathology shows a 2.2 mm melanoma with no lymph node evaluation performed. What is the implication of this omission?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses completion lymph node dissection
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Current guidelines recommend against routine completion dissection. What alternative management should be offered?”
- “The patient is referred to medical oncology and started on adjuvant PD-1 inhibitor therapy. What follow-up strategy do you recommend?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays or mismanages staging
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The patient presents 6 months later with a new palpable axillary mass. What would you do now?”
- “PET/CT shows isolated axillary nodal disease without distant metastasis. How would you manage this?”
- “You perform a therapeutic lymph node dissection. Pathology shows 3 of 12 nodes positive. What adjuvant options are available now?”

critical_decision_points: Interpretation of pathology (Breslow depth, ulceration, mitotic rate)
Selection of surgical margins for excision
Recognition of sentinel lymph node biopsy indication
Management of positive sentinel node (no longer routine completion dissection)
Knowledge of adjuvant systemic therapy (immunotherapy, targeted therapy)
